text:
In this video <https://youtu.be/LayMwCIQAnM> you can see the progress I made on opening up codeflowcanvas so that it is embeddable in other frameworks/libraries like Astro/Angular and React. I've restructured some of the packages that the project uses and published these to NPM. You can see the embedding of codeflowcanvas on its own website using a custom StorageProvider for loading json files from a javascript bundle: <https://www.codeflowcanvas.io/devlog/embedded-codeflowcanvas/> .

This goal of this restructuring is to get codeflowcanvas out of its own silo on various way (for example in the future I want to be able to design flows in a vscode editor and use these together with other framework/libraries without embedding the editor and just run the flows).

A feature that is also made possible by the above is being able to export to external formats like tldraw and the OpenCanvas work-in-progress spec (see <https://www.canvasprotocol.org/>). Different strategies can be implemented to provide different formats.

attachments.title: Embedding codeflowcanvas and exporting to different formats

attachments.text: Working group for establishing interoperability between different infinite canvas tools.
attachments.title: Open Canvas Working Group | OCWG

text:
Umpteenth attempt at stripping away unnecessary rules when teaching programming.

(Just a mockup to convey the idea. Plan is just to use this notation with pen and paper.)

Is this picture intelligible without any explanation?

elements.text:
Umpteenth attempt at stripping away unnecessary rules when teaching programming.

(Just a mockup to convey the idea. Plan is just to use this notation with pen and paper.)

Is this picture intelligible without any explanation?

text:
Yes, but only because I have a sense of what's going on. The first image and the final image feel redundant. Like, why are the physical dimensions in the first image not to scale? I feel like, assuming your goal is to explain the text code, the order should be:

1. Text code.
2. Final image overlaid with measurements.
3. Final image without measurements.

elements.text: Yes, but only because I have a sense of what's going on

The first image and the final image feel redundant. Like, why are the physical dimensions in the first image not to scale? I feel like, assuming your goal is to explain the text code, the order should be:
Text code.
Final image overlaid with measurements.
Final image without measurements

text: But if you're also going to explain stuff as you go, rather than letting the diagrams speak for themselves, then I'd use whichever diagrams + explanations go best together.

elements.text: But if you're also going to explain stuff as you go, rather than letting the diagrams speak for themselves, then I'd use whichever diagrams + explanations go best together

text: The goal is to use just the notation of the first picture on pen and paper. The rest is just to explain the idea here.

elements.text: The goal is to use just the notation of the first picture on pen and paper. The rest is just to explain the idea here.

text: Ah, okay. Then yeah, I'd draw the boxes roughly to scale.

elements.text: Ah, okay
Then yeah, I'd draw the boxes roughly to scale

text: And I'd also make those lines for position extend right to the edge of the paper. Otherwise, you'll possibly need to introduce the idea of the origin, and that's tricky.

elements.text: And I'd also make those lines for position extend right to the edge of the paper
Otherwise, you'll possibly need to introduce the idea of the origin, and that's tricky

text: Which of course means if you're showing two boxes, their position lines or shapes will probably cross unless you choose them carefully.

elements.text: Which of course means if you're showing two boxes, their position lines or shapes will probably cross unless you choose them carefully

text:
The reason I'm thinking the boxes are not (shouldn't be) to scale is this is still just notation. Code for the thing vs the thing.

The only problem I'm solving is that the order of 4 numbers is arbitrary and hard to remember for 6 year olds who have tiny short-term memories.

elements.text:

The only problem I'm solving is that the order of 4 numbers is arbitrary and hard to remember for 6 year olds who have tiny short-term memories.

text: The only relative position is which instruction comes first (so yes, still introducing brain damage by Dijkstra's lights)

elements.text: The only relative position is which instruction comes first (so yes, still introducing brain damage by Dijkstra's lights)

text: Right, because the order of the numbers and order of statements is total bogus forced on us by textual coding. Evil evil!

elements.text: Right, because the order of the numbers and order of statements is total bogus forced on us by textual coding. Evil evil!

text: So, like, given these constraints, the thing you have is obvious in hindsight. But I'm not sure if the incidental complexity (like stuff not being sized correctly) is a help or a hindrance.

elements.text: So, like, given these constraints, the thing you have is obvious in hindsight
But I'm not sure if the incidental complexity (like stuff not being sized correctly) is a help or a hindrance

text: The point is to introduce order for situations (coming soon!) where it _will_ matter.

elements.text: The point is to introduce order for situations (coming soon!) where it
will
matter.

text: Good point. Time for human experiments.

elements.text: Good point. Time for human experiments.

text: Also, remember one of the Zelda lessons: it's often best to show the player a locked door before showing them the key.

elements.text: Also, remember one of the Zelda lessons: it's often best to show the player a locked door before showing them the key

text: So, for the case where order does matter, maybe find a way to help them discover what happens if you don't have the "right" order.

elements.text: So, for the case where order does matter, maybe find a way to help them discover what happens if you don't have the "right" order

text:
Oh yes. Recent conversation, not related to programming:

Me: you have to do the steps in order.
Kid: why?
Me: the order usually matters.
Kid: why?
Me: can you do things after you die?
Kid: no.
Me: See? The order matters.

There's your door :smile: Unless you meant something else?

text: That's good

text: (The topic was: he had to clean up his room before he could have a book from high up the bookshelf.)

elements.text: (The topic was: he had to clean up his room before he could have a book from high up the bookshelf.)

text: So yeah, I think I have this philosophical disagreement with Dijkstra and a bunch of FP folks. The order often _does_ matter. Even when it doesn't matter, I mostly have an easier time visualizing a single sequence of steps rather than imagining a society of mind inside the computer doing independent work. So why bother introducing parallelism when it's harder to imagine and not universally applicable.

elements.text: So yeah, I think I have this philosophical disagreement with Dijkstra and a bunch of FP folks. The order often
does

matter. Even when it doesn't matter, I mostly have an easier time visualizing a single sequence of steps rather than imagining a society of mind inside the computer doing independent work. So why bother introducing parallelism when it's harder to imagine and not universally applicable.

text:
This is purely for introducing programming, of course. I can see how parallelism or non-determinism is useful for correctness.

Then again, I've never been good at the correctness. Probably because of the brain damage..

elements.text:

text: I haven't spent enough time inside an environment where the order truly doesn't matter

elements.text: I haven't spent enough time inside an environment where the order truly doesn't matter

text: It's fundamentally impossible. Even Haskellers will agree that some domains require ordering. Their goal is to limit order to where it's strictly necessary.

elements.text: It's fundamentally impossible. Even Haskellers will agree that some domains require ordering. Their goal is to limit order to where it's strictly necessary.

text: s/environment/domain

elements.text: s/environment/domain

text: Order always matters. In FP, it's encoded in the nesting of functions. f(g(x)) is different from g(f(x)) (assuming both make sense).

elements.text: Order always matters. In FP, it's encoded in the nesting of functions. f(g(x)) is different from g(f(x)) (assuming both make sense).
